tasks.taskName: Embrace Food Citizenship
tasks.taskDescription:
Read the Food Citizenship manifesto. What is one action you could take to practice food citizenship?
Share this to social media using the hashtags
#foodcitizen #PlanEATaryQuest

tasks.taskName: Diet Impact Reduction Action
tasks.taskDescription:
Read the CSIRO webpage on Reducing the environmental impact of your diet.
What is one achievable change you could make to reduce the impact of your diet?

tasks.taskName: Ethical Food Choice
tasks.taskDescription:
Visit the website Shop Ethical. Look up a core food category (e.g. cereals or dairy) and identify a product and brand that rates well.
Consider switching to this brand and share your experience on social media using the hashtags
#ethicalfood #PlanEATaryQuest

tasks.taskName: Livestock and Alternatives Summary
tasks.taskDescription:
Review Meat, metrics and mindsets: exploring the debates on the role of livestock and alternatives in diets and farming by Sustainable Table.
How would you summarise this article in one sentence?

tasks.taskName: Sustainable Sourcing: Guides for Ethical Producers
tasks.taskDescription:
Do some research to find producers that promote environmental sustainability and animal welfare.
o Beef Sustainable Table Guide
o Pork Sustainable Table Guide
o Eggs Sustainable Table Guide
o Dairy Sustainable Table Guide
o Seafood SAFS app (Status of Australia Fish Stocks) or Sustainable Seafood Guide

tasks.taskName: Reflection on Animal-Derived Food Choices
tasks.taskDescription:
Choose one animal-derived food that you eat regularly (e.g. beef, pork, poultry, fish, seafood, eggs) and reflect on:
o The various indicators/measures of environmental impact;
o Where you purchase this from, and;
o How much you know about the way in which it’s been produced.

tasks.taskName: Exploring Regenerative Agriculture in Beef Supply
tasks.taskDescription: Find out about regenerative agriculture and search for a local beef supplier using these practices. How does your current meat supplier rate compared to this supplier? Would you consider switching? Why, or why not?

tasks.taskName: Webinar Insights on Sustainable Dietetics
tasks.taskDescription:
Dietitian Connection has some great resources. Take the time to watch some of their webinars including Consumer behaviour, diet and sustainability: how are they connected? Answer the questions: what is one new thing you learned? What implications does it have for your area of dietetic practice (or if you are a student, the area of practice that most interests you)?
Unlocking sustainable eating. How can dietitians empower their clients to eat more sustainably? is another informative webinar. After watching, answer the question: What are two things presented that the public might find surprising?

tasks.taskName: CPD Goals and Self-Assessment for Dietitians
tasks.taskDescription: For Dietitians Australia members: Do a self-assessment and create CPD goals and tasks as part of your annual CPD plan: https://icdasustainability.org/learning-modules/sustainability-self-assessment/

tasks.taskName: Key Takeaways from Australian Diets and Climate Impact
tasks.taskDescription: Read the published paper, Diets within Environmental limits: the climate impact of current and recommended Australian diets. What are at least 3 key messages you take from it? Answer the following questions: which two foods are climate neutral in Australia and why? What are two other non-climate indicators of environmental impact?

tasks.taskName: Environmental Impact of Food: Communication Challenge
tasks.taskDescription:
For Dietitians Australia members:
View the DA Food & Environment Interest Group webinars, Measuring the environmental impact of food, and Assessing the environmental impact of food via the Centre For Advanced Learning. Answer the question: what would be your 1-minute lift conversation about the environmental impact of food? Record yourself on video. Seek feedback about it from a colleague or friend to determine if you communicated clearly and convincingly. Upload to social media if you wish using the hashtag #PlanEATaryQuest.

tasks.taskName: Support Indigenous Food Companies
tasks.taskDescription: Research examples of food companies that are Indigenous-owned and take action to promote (e.g., share on your socials, purchase some products from them, etc.). Research your favourite food product that uses native ingredients to see who benefits financially from product sales (e.g., is the business Indigenous-owned?). Seasoned Traveller.

tasks.taskName: Explore Australian Bushfoods
tasks.taskDescription: Watch SBS Food’s ‘12 Australian bushfoods you may not know about’ (8 mins) to gain some insight into bush foods and how these can be cooked.

tasks.taskName: Find Ethically Sourced Native Cuisine
tasks.taskDescription: Do some research to see if there are restaurants, cafes, or caterers near you that are ethically sourcing and serving Australian native ingredients. Consider whether you could host your next social gathering at, or have a work function catered by, these businesses. Indigenous Australian-Owned Food & Restaurant Directory - Seasoned Traveller.

tasks.taskName: Explore Australian Native Ingredients
tasks.taskDescription: Familiarise yourself with at least one Australian native ingredient to learn about its history, properties, flavour, and culinary use. Australian Native Food & Botanicals.

tasks.taskName: Incorporate Native Ingredients into Your Menu
tasks.taskDescription: Incorporate at least one new Australian native ingredient into a meal on your weekly menu.

tasks.taskName: Cooking with Native Ingredients: Warndu Mai
tasks.taskDescription:
Warndu Mai - Good Food’ is a great starting point if you are interested in trying some native recipes.
This cookbook was created by Damnie Coulthard and Rebecca Sullivan and serves as an excellent, easy-to-follow guide to native flavours and ingredients.

tasks.taskName: Learn from Tracy Hardy: Wattleseed Nutrition
tasks.taskDescription: Learn from Tracy Hardy (Accredited Practising Dietitian) by following @wattleseednutrition on Instagram or completing one of her workshops

tasks.taskName: Climate Change and Australia's Native Food Industry
tasks.taskDescription: For food and sustainability, have a read of articles such as ‘How climate change is reshaping Australia's native food industry’ to explore various First Nation perspectives on the impact of climate change on native foods.

tasks.taskName: Engage with the National Indigenous Times
tasks.taskDescription: Subscribe or take a look at the National Indigenous Times.

tasks.taskName: Explore Pre-Colonial Agriculture in "Dark Emu"
tasks.taskDescription: Read Bruce Pascoe’s ‘Dark Emu’ to learn about pre- colonial agriculture and food systems.

tasks.taskName: Explore First Nations Agriculture through Black Duck Foods
tasks.taskDescription: Investigate Bruce Pascoe’s website to explore First Nation’s agriculture.

tasks.taskName: Source Local Honey: Save the Bees
tasks.taskDescription: Try sourcing your honey locally. Using the 'Save the bees' website, navigate to the 'Honey Map' tab to assist with finding a local gem. www.beethecure.com.au

tasks.taskName: Transform Your Nature Strip into Edible Space
tasks.taskDescription: Create an edible nature strip by converting the existing grassy area next to the footpath into a space abundant with a variety of edible plants.

tasks.taskName: Choose Local: Country-of-Origin for Fresh Produce
tasks.taskDescription: Check the country-of-origin of fresh produce and avoid imported produce.

tasks.taskName: Explore Your Local Farmers Market
tasks.taskDescription: Investigate your local farmers market. To find your local market go to www.farmersmarkets.org.au. When you are there, try to interact with the local producers to learn more about the products. This may change/challenge the way you think about your food when you next go grocery shopping.

tasks.taskName: Get Involved in Community Gardens
tasks.taskDescription:
Visit your local council’s website to find a list of community gardens and community food swaps within your area. There are several ways you could get involved:
- Volunteering: help with gardening tasks
- Join workshops: participate in workshops offered by the community garden to learn about gardening techniques, composting, and worm farming.
- Gardening plots: Rent a garden plot to cultivate your own plants and contribute to the overall garden.
- Connect with others: Interact with fellow gardeners, volunteers, and organizers to build relationships and exchange knowledge.

tasks.taskName: Explore Local and Native Foods
tasks.taskDescription:
Research a uniquely local food to your area or Australian state and learn about/become familiar with what is grown in your area.
This may be an introduced food or a wild ingredient (mushrooms, Warrigal greens, native mint, lemon myrtle, finger limes, Davidson plum etc).

tasks.taskName: Handy Seasonal Food Guides for Meal Planning
tasks.taskDescription:
Browse seasonal food guides and consider keeping a copy handy either on your fridge or phone to help plan meals and shopping lists. See a few of our favourites below:
- https://www.sustainabletable.org.au/journal/seasonal-produce-guide (Australia) (7)
http://seasonalfoodguide.com/ (by state) (8)

tasks.taskName: Joining a Community Garden for Local Produce
tasks.taskDescription: Find a community garden in your area to grow local, seasonal produce with others. https://communitygarden.org.au/ (9)

tasks.taskName: Exploring Local Farmers Markets
tasks.taskDescription: Explore your local farmer’s markets. You will likely discover a variety of fruits, vegetables, and other produce that you might not find in a regular supermarket.

tasks.taskName: Seasonal Recipes for Fresh Produce
tasks.taskDescription:
Find some great recipes using seasonal fruit and vegetables (Sum/Aut/Win/Spr).
Try searching online for recipes using the seasonal ingredient, for example search “eggplant recipes” or “pear recipes”

tasks.taskName: Cultivating Your Home Garden
tasks.taskDescription:
Develop your green-thumb and plant some veggies, herbs or fruit trees (in a garden or in pots), considering what grows well in your area.
Share a photo of any home-grown goodies on your socials, using the hashtags #homegrown #kitchengarden #planeataryquest

tasks.taskName: Flexible Shopping Lists for Seasonal Produce
tasks.taskDescription:
When preparing your shopping list, rather than listing specific fresh items, allow some flexibility to purchase in-season items by colour or group (eg. “greens”,
“hand fruit”, “orange-veg” etc).

tasks.taskName: Weekly Plant Food Tracker
tasks.taskDescription: Create a list of the plant foods you eat across a week. What category could you try and get a few more plants from? See this plant food tracker from Dietitian Connection for inspiration (8).

tasks.taskName: Plant-Based Ingredient Swap in Your Favorite Meal
tasks.taskDescription:
Choose a favourite meal and substitute one of the animal-based ingredients (e.g. meat) for something plant-based.
For example using lentils instead of mince in pasta sauce, or tofu instead of chicken in a stir-fry.

tasks.taskName: Weekly Plant Food Swap Challenge
tasks.taskDescription:
Once a week, swap out a common plant food for something new or different.
For example, switch pasta for quinoa, rice for barley, oats for chia seeds, or potato for sweet potato.

tasks.taskName: Incorporate Nuts into Your Daily Diet
tasks.taskDescription:
Nuts are a common forgotten plant food but are nutritional powerhouses.
Add a serving of nuts each day such as a handful in the afternoon, added to breakfast cereal, crushed on a salad, in a nut-based spread on toast or added to smoothies.

tasks.taskName: Explore Solutions to Reduce Dietary Eco-Footprint
tasks.taskDescription: Is a plant-based diet the only solution to reducing our dietary eco-footprint? Read this Australian research and suggest other effective ways to achieve this goal (9).

tasks.taskName: Weekly Wildcard Plant-Food Challenge
tasks.taskDescription:
Once a week or whenever possible, purchase an unfamiliar ‘wildcard’ plant-food to create a meal with.
Make sure it is in-season and try to source it from somewhere other than the supermarket (farmers market, local producer, community garden).

tasks.taskName: Promote Plant-Based Recipes and Community Engagement
tasks.taskDescription:
Share and promote plant-based recipes among your friends, work colleagues and in your community.
Have a vegetarian dinner party
Take a vegetarian dish to a ‘bring-a-plate’ gatherings
Create Meatless Monday at work
Share recipes and photos of your vegetarian meals on social media using the hashtag #plantbased

tasks.taskName: Key Insights from the FAO Report on Animal Source Foods
tasks.taskDescription: To begin your journey read the FAO report: Contribution of terrestrial animal source food to healthy diets for improved nutrition and health outcomes (7) and compile a list of key messages.

tasks.taskName: Explore Mycoprotein: Food Security and Environmental Benefits
tasks.taskDescription: Read this paper about mycoprotein and its potential food security and environmental advantages. (10)

tasks.taskName: Cooking with Mycoprotein: Recipe Modification Challenge
tasks.taskDescription: Watch Quorn Foods ‘Magic of Mycoprotein’ video. (11) Modify a recipe you usually cook and make it with a mycoprotein-based product instead. Share your results on social media using the hashtags #altproteins #mycoprotein.

tasks.taskName: Reflecting on Animal-Derived Protein Choices
tasks.taskDescription:
Choose an animal-derived protein food that you eat regularly (e.g., beef, lamb, pork, poultry, fish, seafood, eggs) and reflect on:
(i) the various aspects of environmental impact;
(ii) where you purchase this from, and
(iii) how much you know about the way in which it’s been produced.
Do some research to find producers that promote environmental sustainability and animal welfare.

tasks.taskName: Convenient Meat-Free and Plant-Based Options
tasks.taskDescription:
If you would like to try eating less meat and you don’t have time to cook from scratch there are many convenient options available.
Choose healthier meat-free, plant-protein and vegan options (choose products with a higher Health Star Rating).

tasks.taskName: Cooking with Kangaroo Meat: A Sustainable Choice
tasks.taskDescription: Read about the nutritional composition of kangaroo meat (8) and how to cook it. (9) Prepare a recipe and share it to social media using the hashtags #sustainablefood #Australianfood #nativefood.

tasks.taskName: Reflect on Cultivated Meat: Considerations and Choices
tasks.taskDescription: Read a review of cultivated meat from Food Frontier. Reflect on whether you would try it, and the factors influencing your decision.

tasks.taskName: Generation Z and Cultured Meat: Social Science Insights
tasks.taskDescription: Read social science about Generation Z’s perspectives on cultured meat.

tasks.taskName: Explore Dietitian-Approved Plant-Based Recipes
tasks.taskDescription: Try dietitian-approved plant-based recipes on the Doctors for Nutrition Recipe web page.

tasks.taskName: Experiment with Wild Game and Alternative Proteins
tasks.taskDescription: Try a recipe using wild game meats (e.g. kangaroo, rabbit), fish you’ve caught, ‘new-age’ foods including cultivated meat, fungi / mycoprotein or insects.

tasks.taskName: Learn About Edible Insects: Share Your Insights
tasks.taskDescription: Watch National Geographic’s video ‘Edible Insects’. Share what you have learnt with a friend or family member, or share your thoughts on social media using the hashtags #edibleinsects #entomophagy.

tasks.taskName: Pantry & Fridge Stocktake: Identifying Discretionary and Ultra-Processed Foods
tasks.taskDescription:
Do a kitchen stocktake of your pantry and fridge to identify the foods and beverages which are both discretionary foods and/or highly processed or ultra processed foods. Then see what alternatives are available that are less processed and more nutritious.

Tips on how to assess:
- Use the Dietary Guidelines to identify discretionary foods, and/or the Health Star Rating (HSR) of below 3.5 stars.
- Give yourself a free-pass for processed products that help you prepare balanced, tasty meals, such as flavour bases, spice kits and condiments, which could be classified as Group 2 Foods ‘Processed culinary ingredients’
- To estimate the impact of processing, ask yourself:
o How far removed is this food from its original form? Further removed = highly processed.
o How much nutrition has been lost in its processing? A lot = highly processed.
o Would it be classified by NOVA as an UPF?

tasks.taskName: Healthy Takeaway Alternatives Challenge
tasks.taskDescription:
Choose one or more of the highly processed, nutritionally poor foods or takeaway meals you frequently purchase.
- Is there a healthier alternative to this food?
- Could you make it from scratch with minimally processed ingredients?
- Can you come up with a version of a takeaway meal to make at home with healthier ingredients and less packaging? e.g. home-made Mediterranean vegetable pizza instead of frozen pepperoni pizza, or natural yoghurt with honey and nuts instead of a chocolate-coated ice cream on a stick?

Share your recipe on social media, using the hashtag #HomeMade or #BetterThanTakeaway

tasks.taskName: Local Love: Find Your Favorite Processed Treat!
tasks.taskDescription:
Think of a favourite food/beverage you enjoy that is considered highly processed and nutritionally poor, for example an apple pie, block of chocolate or alcoholic beverage. Could you find it produced locally, such as from a bakery, chocolatier, or small brewer/distiller? This way you can support your local food system and the people in it.

Share your experience using the hashtag #LocalFood

tasks.taskName: Evaluate the NOVA Classification System for Ultra-Processed Foods
tasks.taskDescription:
Download the ‘NOVA Open Food Facts’ app to help with understanding its classifications and what makes an ‘ultra processed food.’ Consider the following questions:
- Can you see any issues with this system?
- How well does this system fit within the Australian Dietary Guidelines?
- Have you found foods that NOVA would classify as UPF but you think are OK for health and the environment? Why?

tasks.taskName: Grocery Trolley Nutritional Audit
tasks.taskDescription:
When shopping at a supermarket, keep track of how much of your trolley comprises foods from the perimeter (fruit, veg, bakery, deli) compared to the middle aisles. Typically, highly processed, nutritionally poor foods are found closer to the centre. Can you set yourself a goal that the majority of items come from the outside aisles and less from the middle?
- Are there exceptions to this ‘foods in centre aisles are nutritionally poor‘ rule?
- What foods do you see in the centre aisles that are minimally processed and nutritious?
- What highly processed, nutritionally poor foods can you spot in the outer ‘fresh’ aisles?

tasks.taskName: Key Messages on Diet and Climate Change from Selected Articles
tasks.taskDescription:
Read these:
- Hendrie GA, Baird D, Ridoutt B et al.. Overconsumption of Energy and Excessive Discretionary Food Intake Inflates Dietary Greenhouse Gas Emissions in Australia. Nutrients. 2016 Oct 31;8(11):690. doi: 10.3390/nu8110690. PMID: 27809233; PMCID: PMC5133078. Available from: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27809233/
- Forbes S, Bicknell E, Guilovica L, Wingrove K, Charlton K. A Rapid Review of the Environmental Impacts Associated with Food Consumption in Australia and New Zealand. Current nutrition reports. 2021;10(4):334–51.

tasks.taskName: Processed Foods Discussion Insights
tasks.taskDescription:
Read this article: Lockyer S, Spiro A, Berry S et al. How do we differentiate not demonise – Is there a role for healthier processed foods in an age of food insecurity? Proceedings of a roundtable event. Nutrition Bulletin 2023;48: 278– 295. Available from: https://doi.org/10.1111/nbu.12617

Q: If you were at a BBQ with a group of friends and someone asked you your opinion about processed foods, what are the three main points you’d say in response?

tasks.taskName: Meal Planning & Smart Shopping
tasks.taskDescription: Plan meals and use a shopping list to buy only what you need. Download some helpful apps from this list

tasks.taskName: Australia's Food Waste Reduction Commitment
tasks.taskDescription: Read about Australia’s commitment and roadmap to halving food waste by 2030 here: Reducing Australia’s food waste - DCCEEW.

tasks.taskName: Leftover Management and Food Waste Audit
tasks.taskDescription: Don’t discard leftovers. Consider how they could be used, such as freezing for another day or transforming them into a new meal. Record in a diary what food is wasted in your bin (quantities if possible e.g. 2 slices bread) or complete a food waste audit (e.g weighed food waste record) (see tool here).

tasks.taskName: Inventory Check: Optimize Your Shopping List by Assessing Your Fridge and Freezer
tasks.taskDescription: Take a good look in your fridge and freezer when making a shopping list to avoid overbuying

tasks.taskName: Proper Food Storage for Longevity
tasks.taskDescription: Store food according to manufacturers/producers instructions properly to extend the life of your food

tasks.taskName: Smart Recipe Selection for Leftover Ingredients
tasks.taskDescription: Select recipes wisely to avoid wasting leftover ingredients (think one ingredient, but 2 recipes)

tasks.taskName: Label and Organize Perishable Foods
tasks.taskDescription: Label perishable foods in the fridge with the date and use while it is still safe (you can use masking tape and a black marker). Bring the food to be eaten first to the front of the shelf

tasks.taskName: Buy Short-Date Foods Mindfully
tasks.taskDescription: Only buy short date-marked food on sale if you will eat them, or else they will be wasted

tasks.taskName: Creative Uses for Non-Edible Food Waste
tasks.taskDescription: Utilise non-edible food waste creatively and safely in compost, stocks and broths, vinegar, cleaning, mulch or animal feed

tasks.taskName: Understand Use-By vs. Best-Before Dates to Reduce Food Waste
tasks.taskDescription: Educate yourself and others on the difference between ‘use-by’ and ‘best-before’ dates to reduce unnecessary waste of edible food by viewing and sharing this video.

tasks.taskName: Implement 'Use It Up Tape' in Kitchens
tasks.taskDescription: Order ‘use it up tape’ from OzHarvest for free, and implement it in home freezer, pantry and workplace kitchens. Simply label food or keep a shelf labeled to have a visual reminder of what needs to be used up soon.

tasks.taskName: Improve Composting Skills through Workshops, Tutorials, and Educational Resources
tasks.taskDescription: Learn how to compost correctly by attending a composting workshop, look up tutorials on YouTube, buying a guidebook or read this blog here from the Good Living Team at the South Australian Department for Environment and Water.

tasks.taskName: Explore Local Food Waste Disposal Options: Composting, Farm Animals, and FOGO Services
tasks.taskDescription: Investigate what options there are available in your council or area for food waste such as composting or farm animals that could consume your food waste. You can check out the interactive map on the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water site to see if FOGO is available in your council area or download the sharewaste app and meet neighbours, recycle organics.

tasks.taskName: Minimize Edible Food Waste: At Home and On-the-Go
tasks.taskDescription: Aim for zero edible food waste into landfill in your house and when eating/drinking out of the house

tasks.taskName: Promote Responsible Food Waste Management through Social Media Engagement
tasks.taskDescription:
Help educate others about responsible food waste management e.g. post a photo of your new management strategy on
social media and add a hashtag #planEATaryquest

tasks.taskName: Advocate for FOGO Collection Implementation in Your Local Council
tasks.taskDescription: Lobby your local Council to start the FOGO collection in your area

tasks.taskName: Feed Animals Safely at Home
tasks.taskDescription: Feed animals at home if safe and able to do so

tasks.taskName: Set Up and Maintain a Home Composting System
tasks.taskDescription: Source a worm farm, compost bin or Bokashi bin for your household and learn how to maintain and benefit from it

tasks.taskName: Share Leftover Food with Colleagues/Neighbours
tasks.taskDescription: Share leftover food with others by taking food to work or give to neighbours, let them know in advance

tasks.taskName: Food Packaging Waste Analysis and Alternatives
tasks.taskDescription: Record what food packaging you discard and investigate if there are other options available with less packaging (i.e. dried beans vs canned)

tasks.taskName: Pesky Plastics Quiz and Social Media Share
tasks.taskDescription: Complete the Pesky Plastics Quiz tool to discover the items you use and decide what you would like to refuse. Share what you decide on social media using #planEATary.

tasks.taskName: Food Storage: Reuse and Upcycle Household Items
tasks.taskDescription: Look around your house to see what items can be reused, upcycled or repurposed in some way for storing food

tasks.taskName: Reduce Single-Serve Product Purchases
tasks.taskDescription: Avoid purchasing single serve products

tasks.taskName: Use Reusable Shopping Bags
tasks.taskDescription: Shop with your own reusable bags

tasks.taskName: Bulk Purchasing to Minimize Packaging
tasks.taskDescription: Buy foods in bulk or larger quantities to reduce individual packaging

tasks.taskName: Sustainable Food Packaging Choices
tasks.taskDescription: Buy foods with zero or less packaging, or biodegradable or recyclable packaging (i.e. glass, cans)

tasks.taskName: Use Reusable Containers for Bulk Purchases
tasks.taskDescription: Take your own reusable containers and/or bags when buying loose/bulk items (fruit, vegetables, nuts, beans)

tasks.taskName: Support Local Farmers Markets
tasks.taskDescription: Shop at farmers markets as many products are sold without any packaging

tasks.taskName: DIY Cloth Bags from Unwanted Fabric
tasks.taskDescription: Make your own cloth bags from unwanted fabric to avoid them going to landfill

tasks.taskName: DIY Fizzy Soft Drinks with Sparkling Water Machine
tasks.taskDescription: Make your own fizzy soft drinks using a sparkling water machine and flavoured syrups such as SodaStream

tasks.taskName: Subscription to Zero-Waste Produce Box
tasks.taskDescription: Subscribe to a fruit & vegetable box service to avoid packaging

tasks.taskName: Scratch Cooking & Recipe Sharing
tasks.taskDescription:
Make your own food from scratch to reduce the amount of packaging waste generated. Perhaps share your recipe online
and why you cooked it using #planEATary

tasks.taskName: Batch Cooking and Freezing Legumes and Grains
tasks.taskDescription: Batch cook legumes and grains in large amounts and store in meal-size portions in the freezer using your own containers instead of purchasing cans

tasks.taskName: Advocacy for Sustainable Packaging in Food Businesses
tasks.taskDescription: Advocate for food businesses to switch to biodegradable/compostable packaging and/or use recyclable packaging

tasks.taskName: Creative Reuse of Food Packaging
tasks.taskDescription: Explore creative re-use of food packaging yourself, like using jars for food gifts such as pickles or as pencil holders. Take a picture and share it using the hashtag #planEATary

tasks.taskName: Eco-Friendly Leftover Storage
tasks.taskDescription: Avoid plastic wrap - store your leftovers in reusable containers, place a plate over the container or switch to wax wraps

tasks.taskName: Familiarization with the Australasian Recycling Label (ARL)
tasks.taskDescription: Learn about the Australasian Recycling Label (ARL).

tasks.taskName: Promote Responsible Recycling Practices
tasks.taskDescription: Be a good recycler, and ‘check it before you chuck it’ using the Australian recycling label.

tasks.taskName: Local Council Recycling Information Check
tasks.taskDescription: Check out recycling available in your local Council.

tasks.taskName: Cash-Back Recycling Initiatives
tasks.taskDescription: Make money by using cash-back recycling schemes like ‘Return & Earn’ for drinks bottles/cans

tasks.taskName: Recycling Contamination Reduction
tasks.taskDescription: Reduce contamination of recycling bins by flattening boxes, emptying food and liquid from containers, and not putting plastic bags into the recycling bin

tasks.taskName: Promote Reusable Items
tasks.taskDescription: Bring a reusable cup (Choose to Up Cup), water bottle, eating utensils and/or reusable straw and encourage others to do so.

tasks.taskName: Bring Your Own Containers for Food and Water
tasks.taskDescription: Take food and water in your own containers from home when going out and about (cheaper and better for you too)

tasks.taskName: Dine-In Instead of Takeaway
tasks.taskDescription: Eat in at a cafe or restaurant rather than purchasing take away

tasks.taskName: Identify Sustainable Cafés with Swap and Go or Mug Library
tasks.taskDescription: Find a Responsible Cafe or a cafe which offers ‘Swap and go’ or a ‘mug library’

tasks.taskName: Identify and Advocate for Water Refill Stations
tasks.taskDescription: Find out where you can refill your reusable water bottle when you are out and about. Your town, city or state may have a water refill station map such as Unity Water. Or advocate for one by writing a letter to your local council. If you find one you may want to share how it can be used online #planEATary.

tasks.taskName: Procurement of Compostable Takeaway Supplies
tasks.taskDescription: Purchase from vendors who offer compostable takeaway utensils and containers

tasks.taskName: Responsible Recycling and Composting on the Go
tasks.taskDescription: When out and about, take recyclable items/food waste home if community recycling is not available and you can recycle/compost responsibly at home

tasks.taskName: Safe Leftover Management
tasks.taskDescription: Take home any leftovers (if safe to do so)

tasks.taskName: Use Personal Containers for Take-Away
tasks.taskDescription: When buying take-away take your own containers

tasks.taskName: Sustainable Meal Packaging Practices
tasks.taskDescription: Wash and re-use or recycle packaging of home delivered/take-away meals, or avoid home delivery altogether

tasks.taskName: Promote Proper Recycling Practices with Recycle Mate
tasks.taskDescription: Do not contaminate recycling bins with packaging which cannot be recycled - check with Recycle Mate. You could download the app on your phone and share it with friends.

tasks.taskName: Workplace Recycling Advocacy and Education
tasks.taskDescription: Advocate for recycling facilities in your workplace and educate others on their proper use

tasks.taskName: Community Litter Cleanup and Awareness
tasks.taskDescription: Help to clean up your local area to prevent litter entering the natural environment, and encourage others to do the same. For example - 3 for the sea. Take a photo of what you collect and share it on social media using the hashtag #planEATary.

tasks.taskName: Create a Social Media Flyer on the Planetary Health Benefits of Breastfeeding
tasks.taskDescription: Read the following UNICEF page (5) and develop a one page flyer/poster/infographic on the planetary health benefits of breastfeeding suitable for sharing on social media, using the hashtag #Breastfeeding and #breastisbest.

tasks.taskName: Research Local Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI) Accredited Facilities
tasks.taskDescription: Investigate which local health care facilities are accredited with the Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI).

tasks.taskName: Support Breastfeeding Mothers with Encouragement and Resources
tasks.taskDescription: Support breastfeeding mothers within your family, friends and community by offering encouragement, support and resources. Checkout the Australian Breastfeeding Association for information, resources, support and education groups in your local area.(7)

tasks.taskName: Identify or Advocate for Comfortable Baby Care Rooms in the Community
tasks.taskDescription: Find comfortable places to breastfeed away from home at Baby Care Rooms. (9) If you can’t find any, lobby for comfortable and safe spaces for breastfeeding in your local community.

tasks.taskName: Participate in WHO World Breastfeeding Week and Share Campaign Messages
tasks.taskDescription: Participate in WHO World Breastfeeding Week and share campaign messages on social media.(8)

tasks.taskName: Breastfeeding Events Participation
tasks.taskDescription: Attend or host breastfeeding events such as support groups or awareness events

tasks.taskName: Workplace Breastfeeding Advocacy
tasks.taskDescription: Provide or advocate for a comfortable and safe space for breastfeeding in your workplace

tasks.taskName: Regulate Infant Formula Advertising
tasks.taskDescription: Infant formula should not be advertised/promoted to the public. Report inappropriate promotion of infant formula.(11)

tasks.taskName: Understand Employer Responsibilities for Breastfeeding Support
tasks.taskDescription: Breastfeeding is protected by anti-discrimination laws.(10) Find out what employers are expected to do in order to provide a supportive, non-discriminatory workplace for breastfeeding women.

tasks.taskName: Model Breastfeeding Behavior
tasks.taskDescription: Model ideal behaviour by breastfeeding yourself if you can, or support your partner to breastfeed

tasks.taskName: Analysis of The Conversation Article on Breastfeeding
tasks.taskDescription:
Read The Conversation article (12) on breastfeeding and answer these questions:
Who/What do the public health practitioners suggest should play a bigger role in increasing breastfeeding rates?
What are the five things the authors suggest require investment to increase breastfeeding rates?
What should health professionals keep in mind when promoting breastfeeding to women?

tasks.taskName: Review of the Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI) and Accreditation Process
tasks.taskDescription:
Review the Baby-friendly hospital Initiative Australia (BFHI) (6) and answer the following questions:
- What are the ten steps to successful breastfeeding?
- How does a healthcare facility become accredited with BFHI?

tasks.taskName: Analysis of the MAIF Agreement and Related Questions
tasks.taskDescription:
Read the summary of the ‘Marketing in Australia of Infant Formulas’ (MAIF) (11) Manufacturers and Importers’ (MAIF) Agreement and answer the following questions:
- Which International Code is the MAIF based on?
- What are the four aims of the MAIF?
- Give one example of a complaint made about failure to comply with the MAIF agreement?
- What is a current issue related to the MAIF that has public health advocates concerned?
